Award.AwardTitle: Testing contrasting models for the distribution of hydrothermal circulation in subducting crust
Award.AbstractNarration:
Subduction zones are where one of Earth's tectonic plates moves under another resulting in many of the world's largest earthquakes and damaging tsunamis. One example is the 2011 earthquake and tsunami in northern Japan that killed more than 20,000 people and crippled the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex. These earthquakes arise from friction on the subduction zone fault that separates the two tectonic plates. The temperature of the subduction fault zone affects this friction and can control the size and distribution of earthquakes. In addition, subduction zone temperatures affect a wide range of other physical and chemical processes, including the generation of magma that supplies nearby volcanoes. To understand these processes, it is important to accurately estimate subduction zone temperatures. Recent discoveries show that seawater circulating within the subducting tectonic plates is an important control on subduction zone temperatures. This project will examine how fractures that open in the upper part of a tectonic plate as it bends down into a subduction zone affect seawater circulation in the system and how that affects subduction zone temperatures. The project will develop numerical thermal models for seven subduction zones. Application of the results of this research has direct societal benefit, by informing earthquake hazard estimates. In addition, the project will enhance education at New Mexico Tech, a STEM-focused Hispanic-serving institution. A graduate student will be trained in geophysics and hydrogeology. Results of the project will be incorporated into "using data in the classroom" efforts, improving hands-on experience in undergraduate courses.

Accurate subduction zone thermal models are necessary to understand frictional behavior, metamorphic reaction progress, release of volatiles from the subducting slab, mantle wedge hydration, subduction dynamics, and melt generation. Fluid circulation in an oceanic crustal aquifer is an important control on subduction zone temperatures. However, there are contrasting hypotheses for how much of the oceanic crust can host vigorous hydrothermal circulation. Both thickening of the oceanic crustal aquifer via plate bending normal faults and fluid circulation between subducted crust and the crust seaward of the trench may contribute to the advective redistribution of heat that affects subduction zone temperatures. This project will test the hypothesis that the thermal effects of aquifer thickening prior to subduction are greater for slabs with a greater degree of curvature. This project will exploit the fact that aquifer thickening from the outer rise to the trench and continued fluid circulation in subducting crust are expected to produce distinct surface heat flux anomalies (a broad low amplitude anomaly for aquifer thickening; a narrow high amplitude anomaly for fluid circulation in subducting crust) in order to constrain the thermal effects of each process. This will advance our understanding of the fluid circulation process that is an important control on subduction zone temperatures, improving subduction zone thermal models for the seven margins examined in this project and others.

POR.DRECONTENT:
We examined how seawater flowing through oceanic crust can affect temperatures within subduction zones. Accurate estimates of subduction zone temperatures improve our understanding of fault zone behavior, including informing estimates for which portions of the plate boundary fault in subduction zone may be capable of generating earthquakes. Previous research demonstrated that water can carry heat from subducted oceanic crust seaward, where some of the heat can be lost to the ocean, resulting in a cooler subduction zone than if the fluid flow were not occurring. In this study, we examined how the bending of a subducting lithospheric plate can increase the thickness of the aquifer in the upper oceanic crust, affecting fluid and heat transport in the system, and in turn affecting subduction zone temperatures. 

The focus of this study was identifying the processes that control subduction zone temperatures. Observations of heat flux across the seafloor are required to constrain the thermal state of oceanic crust and the processes controlling the temperature distribution is the system. Two subduction zones with outstanding datasets of seafloor heat flux are the Japan Trench margin offshore northern Japan and the Nankai margin offshore southern Japan. As the Pacific Plate approaches the Japan Trench, it bends more than does the Phillipine Sea Plate approaching the Nankai margin. We hypothesized that the Pacific Plate (which bends more) would have greater aquifer thickening as a result of bend-related faulting, thus would experience a greater thermal influence of the aquifer thickening. We hypothesized that aquifer thickening would have a smaller effect on the Nankai margin.

We found that both aquifer thickening associated with plate bending and fluid circulation between subducted crust and the crust seaward of the trench can contribute to the redistribution of heat that affects subduction zone temperatures. Contrasting processes are required to generate thermal anomalies that are consistent with the observed seafloor heat flux patterns at the Japan Trench and Nankai margins. At the Japan Trench, aquifer thickening as the plate bends on its approach to the subduction zone facilitates the generation of the broad low amplitude heat flux anomaly that extends >100 km seaward of the trench. For the Japan Trench, lateral heat exchange between the subducted aquifer and the crust seaward of the trench may alter the heat flux distribution; it cannot be the sole process generating the observed thermal anomaly. At the Nankai margin, lateral heat exchange between the subducted oceanic crust and the crust seaward of the trench facilitates the generation of a large amplitude heat flux anomaly focused seaward of the trench. For the Nankai margin, thickening of the aquifer as the crust approaches the trench may modify the heat flux distribution; however, in isolation, this process is not sufficient to generate the observed thermal anomaly. 

On the Nankai margin, along the NanTroSEIZE drilling transect, scatter in the surface heat flux observations make it challenging to use heat flux to constrain the thermal state of the system. However, the clay mineral assemblage data from ~2-3 km depth at Integrated Ocean Drilling Program Site C0002 (part of the NanTroSEIZE drilling transect) provides a very useful new constraint on the thermal history for the margin. Our best estimate for the temperature near the updip limit of seismicity on the plate boundary fault in the NanTroSEIZE transect is 125 ˚C. This is derived from the thermal model that results in modeled clay mineral alteration most consistent with the observations at Site C0002.

For the Cascadia margin of the U.S. Pacific Northwest, we found that hydrothermal circulation associated with basement relief generates large anomalies in heat flux across the seafloor at a site offshore Grays Harbor, Washington. The key conclusion from this site is that the anomaly is seafloor heat flux is present even though there is exceptionally thick (>3 km) sediment cover at the Cascadia deformation front. This signal provides a test for the presence of hydrothermal circulation. Possible future studies combining data from multiple sites would allow one to infer whether hydrothermal circulation in the subducting crust is of local or regional importance.
